Award.AwardTitle: GOALI Collaborative Proposal: 3D RF Microsystems using Direct Digital Manufacturing Technology

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objectives Research is proposed that will advance design and fabrication techniques relating to direct digital manufacturing (DDM), or additive manufacturing of three-dimensional, reconfigurable microwave microsystems. DDM is a layer-by-layer fabrication approach which can combine structural, functional and sacrificial materials in a single build of arbitrary-shaped structures. The work will investigate devices that include new transmission line geometries, deployable 3-D antennas and tunable cavity filters. Mechanical reconfiguration based on DDM-produced shape-shifting surfaces will also be studied.

Intellectual Merit DDM has enabled significant technical innovation in a wide range of fields, from bio-medical devices to fuel cells, but utilization in RF/microwave applications is in its infancy. To date, high frequency applications have consisted primarily of the deposition of conductors on conformal surfaces to create antennas and simple interconnects. This project will explore the integration of innovative electronic and mechanical design techniques that are compatible with a low cost, common manufacturing platform to produce 3D microwave systems.

Broader Impacts Reversing the loss of high-tech manufacturing jobs is of vital importance to the Nation?s economic security, and thus the outcomes of this project could have significant societal impact. DDM is also a green technology that eliminates material waste associated with subtractive manufacturing and so has a positive impact on environmental sustainability. The outcomes of the research will be integrated into undergraduate education through joint REU activities between the partnering institutions, and also into the graduate curricula at each school. Graduate student exchanges are planned along with summer internships at Sciperio to enhance professional development.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
The future of consumer, defense and space electronics will be to utilize the structure as the electronics and personalize the item’s shape and function.  Personalized electronics, also known as Mass Customization, are not cost-effective due to the nature of traditional high-volume manufacturing processes.  The next generation of Mass Customization will be enabled by Direct Digital Manufacturing (DDM) or Additive Manufacturing (AM), in which a product design is entered into a computer and the computer controls a machine that prints the electronic device in a 3D fashion.  The global market for consumer electronics alone was almost $900 billion in 2010; the addition of defense and space electronics revenue brings this number to more than a trillion dollars.  Mass Customization will eventually dominate this market. This project lays the foundations for Mass Customization of Radio Frequency (RF) electronic components using AM techniques that have been widely used to produce automotive and airplane components, toys, robotic arms and various other mechanical structures so far. With the imminent deployment of 5G wireless networks, automotive anti-collision radars and various RF sensors used in the Internet of Things (IoT), low cost RF electronics that can be easily designed and produced in environmentally friendly ways and employed in a variety of platforms are of utmost importance with significant national financial implications. Our team has developed design guidelines and methods for designing AM or 3D printed RF electronics that could revolutionize the way consumer, defense and space electronic products are designed and manufactured. Our guidelines and methods were validated with the successful development and demonstration of several 3D printed RF circuits: a) 25-29 GHz (5G) antennas; b) an 8-12 GHz cavity filter; c) a 94 GHz antenna; d) a reconfigurable 8-12 GHz cavity resonator; e) a broadband (0.1-40 GHz) interconnect; and f) a 1-18 GHz plastic package for a low noise amplifier. It is anticipated that AM techniques will eventually allow for the development and low cost production of fully three-dimensional RF components whose design will be limited only by human imagination.


Last Modified: 02/13/2018
Modified by: Ioannis (John) Papapolymerou

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The future of consumer, defense and space electronics will be to utilize the structure as the electronics and personalize the item?s shape and function. Personalized electronics, also known as Mass Customization, are not cost-effective due to the nature of traditional high-volume manufacturing processes. The next generation of Mass Customization will be enabled by Direct Digital Manufacturing (DDM) or Additive Manufacturing (AM), in which a product design is entered into a computer and the computer controls a machine that prints the electronic device in a 3D fashion. The global market for consumer electronics alone was almost $900 billion in 2010; the addition of defense and space electronics revenue brings this number to more than a trillion dollars. Mass Customization will eventually dominate this market. This project lays the foundations for Mass Customization of Radio Frequency (RF) electronic components using AM techniques that have been widely used to produce automotive and airplane components, toys, robotic arms and various other mechanical structures so far. With the imminent deployment of 5G wireless networks, automotive anti-collision radars and various RF sensors used in the Internet of Things (IoT), low cost RF electronics that can be easily designed and produced in environmentally friendly ways and employed in a variety of platforms are of utmost importance with significant national financial implications. Our team has developed design guidelines and methods for designing AM or 3D printed RF electronics that could revolutionize the way consumer, defense and space electronic products are designed and manufactured. Our guidelines and methods were validated with the successful development and demonstration of several 3D printed RF circuits: a) 25-29 GHz (5G) antennas; b) an 8-12 GHz cavity filter; c) a 94 GHz antenna; d) a reconfigurable 8-12 GHz cavity resonator; e) a broadband (0.1-40 GHz) interconnect; and f) a 1-18 GHz plastic package for a low noise amplifier. It is anticipated that AM techniques will eventually allow for the development and low cost production of fully three-dimensional RF components whose design will be limited only by human imagination.
